section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we help plants grow?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Phyllis Root Illustrated by G. Brian Karas
section-block.rac_book_summary: One girl shows that you can build a garden anywhere, as long as you have some soil, sunshine, water, and seeds.

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Dd, Gg, Uu Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_body-text: Have children match the picture for each word: Duck, dog, Goat, gift, Umbrella, up. Invite children to say rhyming words for dog and goat.
To engage children, invite them to sing to the tune of “Row, Row, Row Your Boat”: Plant, plant, plant a seed/ Then we’ll watch it grow/ Up, up, up, up!/ We will see it go!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Anywhere Farm. The author who wrote this book is Phyllis Root. The illustrator who drew the pictures is G. Brian Karas.
Pablo loves reading stories about growing things. This informational text is about a girl who shows that you can make a farm anywhere.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The girl plants a seed in the ground.
What will the girl do next?
In what surprising places can you plant an anywhere farm?
Listen as I say an onset and rime: /l/ /ot/. Can you blend these sounds to make a word? What word can you make?
section.rac_body-text: Repeat with pan, pot, bin, and cup.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Kale is the name of a vegetable. Where did someone plant kale?
Corn is another vegetable. Which word rhymes with corn and tells where someone planted corn?
What animal visitors might come to an anywhere farm? Pretend you are a butterfly and flutter your arms. Why are you curious about this anywhere farm?
The author says you can plant an anywhere farm in a boat or a boot. Which picture shows the boot? Which picture shows the boat?
Let’s think about the guiding question:
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Vegetables can grow in a pot.
Vegetables can grow in a basket.
Vegetables can grow in a shoe.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about some places to grow plants as children watch.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can you grow vegetables in a basket?
You can grow vegetables in a b_____ (basket).
You can grow vegetables in a basket.
Why do you think sunlight is necessary for plants to grow?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When children begin to explore the relationship between rhyming words, they are engaging with “onset and rime.” Onset is any sound that comes before the vowel in a word and rime is the sound of the rest of the word. Playing rhyming games helps children further develop this skill which makes them stronger readers.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Ask and Answer Questions
section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children that part of being an amazing preschooler is to ask and answer questions. Share with them that when they wonder something, they should ask lots of questions about it. Remind children that answering questions is an important part of learning, too—and even the wrong answer is fine because that is how we learn.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to talk about the Mind Builder and ask and answer questions about the book we will read.
Clifford likes when an author puts a question in her book and then answers it. Let’s find this author’s questions.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and ask and answer questions about anywhere farms.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What thing do you see that shows what you need to grow an anywhere farm?
What question does the author ask? What are some of the answers? (MB)
I’ll read the name of each vegetable. Tap your nose if you like to eat the vegetable I name.
What questions do you have about the vegetables you see growing here? (MB)
section.rac_body-text: Select one child at a time to ask a question about one of the vegetables on the page and call on another child to answer.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The author asked, “Who might come to visit your anywhere farm?” The illustrator helps to answer the question. Who do you see in the picture? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Challenge children to role play in pairs to pretend to plant an anywhere farm. Provide props for them to use. Encourage the pairs to ask each other questions and answer them about what they are doing. (MB)
Transcribe children’s speech as they share information about caring for plants.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Asking stimulating and developmentally appropriate questions can help boost the language environment. Think about extending conversations with these questions. What are your plans for those materials? What do you think will happen next? How did you do that? What does this remind you of? (Schwanenflugel, et al., 2005)

section-block.rac_body-text: Provide some soil, radish seeds, containers, and water so that children can experience planting a seed. Choose a sunny location, then have children monitor growth.
Show a tablet, a computer, and a cell phone. For each one, ask: How does your family keep you safe when you use this digital tool? Talk about using them safely in preK.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Anywhere Farm. On the cover, it says that the author is Phyllis Root and the illustrator is G. Brian Karas. What does an author do? What does an illustrator do?
Pablo loves reading informational texts about real people with information that is true.

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: This is the question I want you to think about as we read today: What do seeds need to grow?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What important things does the author tell us we need for an anywhere farm? Why is soil important?
What do you notice about how the seed sprouts? What can the girl do while she patiently waits for the seed to sprout?
The author wrote, “That’s all you’ll need.” What are the things you need? Let’s count them.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: Listen as I say an onset and rime: /s/ /eed/. Can you blend these sounds to make a word? What word can you make?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The girl has a table at a farmers’ market. What is the girl selling to the man? What is the man giving to her?
How could the girl and a family member use a computer or tablet to let people know about this farmers’ market?
What question might this boy ask the girl about the seed she gives him? (MB)
Did you think about the information we read today? Let’s talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do seeds need to grow?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about what seeds need to grow.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do seeds need soil or vegetables to grow?
Why do seeds need soil to grow?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Digital tools can be a great way to expand possibilities for learning. Careful monitoring is the key to making sure children are safe as they explore digital tools.

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children to clap if they ever heard a story with a giant as one of the characters or a story with magic beans. Tell them the story they will hear today has both!
To prepare children for Jack and the Beanstalk, remind them some things in this story could happen in real life and some could never happen in real life.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read a Big Chart called Jack and the Beanstalk. It is a fairy tale.
Pablo loves to read make-believe stories. This poster shows pictures from the fairy tale, Jack and the Beanstalk.
Anywhere Farm is an informational text and Jack and the Beanstalk is a narrative. Both tell about seeds after they are planted.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can we help plants grow?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Caring for Plants
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, then use these prompts to read and discuss the poster together.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This poster shows the story of Jack and the Beanstalk.
section.rac_d-hed_prompt: Jack traded the cow for beans.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What was Jack supposed to do with the cow? Why does he trade the cow for the beans? How does Jack take care of the beans?
Why has Jack climbed up the beanstalk?
Show me how Jack must have looked when he saw the goose lay a golden egg. Why does Jack take the golden goose?
Why is the golden goose safe now? What do you think Jack will do the next time someone wants to give him magic beans?
What happens to the seeds after they are planted in both stories?

section.rac_body-text: Have children in groups of six (Jack, his mother, the old man, the two giants, the golden goose) use classroom materials to act out the fairy tale. Encourage them to include magic beans (seeds) and a beanstalk (a plant) in their dramas.
Provide a writing prompt about caring for plants and give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Frequent exposure to fairy tales benefits children’s creative development. The tales also help develop critical thinking skills in an uncomplicated context and afford children the chance to see that bad things happen to everyone but safely. Being a simple story, they display good versus evil and teach right from wrong in a manner easily seen.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR EARTH | WEEK 3: Caring for Plants

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to say the nursery rhyme “Mary, Mary, Quite Contrary” with these words: Mary, Mary quite contrary, How does your garden grow? With yellow, blue, red, and pink, Pretty flowers, all in a row. Then, replace Mary with the names of children in the class and chant the rhyme several times.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell the book Anywhere Farm. Let’s find the author’s and illustrator’s names on the cover.
The information in the story about growing things is true. Pablo loves to learn new things.
This week we saw how a girl planted a seed. She has a farmers’ market where she sells the vegetables she grows.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Today, think about this guiding question:
How do people help plants stay healthy?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s pretend to plant a seed. Let’s tenderly place it in the ground.
We are careful because we don’t want to harm it.
Let’s pretend to draw a picture of a tomato to put on the marker. Now let’s stick the marker into the ground.
What do these plants need? Let’s take a watering can and give them some water.
How does the illustrator show the different parts of this plant and how it is growing? Point to the sprout. Point to the roots.
Look at this giant sunflower. Make your body as big as this sunflower. Why would it be fun to grow a plant as tall as this sunflower?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to think about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do people help plants stay healthy?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: People can make sure plants have good soil.
People can make sure plants get sunshine.
People can make sure plants get the right amount of water—not too little or too much.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about how people help plants and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What can people give plants the right amount of?
People can give plants the right amount of w_____ (water).
People can give plants the right amount of water.
What might happen if you give plants too much water?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children are already equipped with great pattern recognition skills. When they recite nursery rhymes, they are given a great opportunity to explore the sound patterns that occur in language.
